Strauss’s basic argument holds that because Locke doesn’t make the case that God exists to Strauss’s satisfaction, the seventeenth-century thinker really didn’t believe in God. Since Locke based the concept of natural law on belief in God, Strauss alleges, Locke couldn’t really believe in natural law. Return to text. 48. Strauss, What Is Political Philosophy?
